summary: 2/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a power pole in Buckeystown, Maryland, United States.  There were no casualties, however, as a result of the bombing, five-hundred homes and two industrial facilities lost power.  Windows were also shattered in buildings a quarter of a mile a way.
target1: Power supply of the Frederick Maryland area
propcomment: Over 500 homes and 2 industries temporarily lost power.  Windows were shattered at buildings as far as one quarter of a mile away.
addnotes: The two industries that lost power were Todd Steel and East Alco Aluminum Plant.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at Covington High School in Louisiana, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained minor damages.  The bombing took place six months before the school was integrated.
motive: Suspected motive was to protest school integration.
propcomment: 4-foot hole blown into a wall, stall partitions damaged, and windows shattered.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a gasoline bomb underneath the Armory at the University of Washington in Seattle, United States.  The bomb did not explode and was later discovered and removed.
motive: Protest the War in Vietnam
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/18/1970: Amidst a period racial strife at Cuyahoga Community College in Cleveland, Ohio, United States, unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb that damaged a car of a police officer working as a security guard.
weapdetail: Pipe filled with black powder was utilized as a bomb
propcomment: Automobile was damaged
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Robert W. Peterson, "Crime & the American Response," Facts on File, 1973.

summary: 2/18/1970: Booby trapped handgrenades were discovered wired to a car in the parking lot of the Vallejo Police Department in California, United States.  The device was deactivated.
weapdetail: Military handgrenade wired to a car
addnotes: This was one of many incidents of violence directed again police departments in Northern California at this time (197002130003 and 197002160001).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail at a Federal Building that housed a United States Courthouse in Hartford, Connecticut, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $450 in damages.
target1: United States District Court of Connecticut
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators ignited a firebomb at the Columbia University International Law Library in Manhattan, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained slight damages.
propcomment: Slight damages
addnotes: This attack occurred late at night on February 20.  It was suspected that this attack might have been related to 197002210004, 197002210005, and 197002210003.  However, the Weathermen only claimed credit for 197002210005 in a letter to the New York Times, and did not mention participation in any other attacks on February 21.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.

summary: 2/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed two dynamite bombs at the construction site of the School of Architecture at the University of Washington in Seattle, Washington, United States.  Only one of the two bombs exploded causing little damage.  There were no casualties.
target1: Construction site of Architecture School, University of Washington
propcomment: Minor damage
addnotes: There is a source claiming that one of the perpetrators of the attack, Jeff Desmond, was actually working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (See: Dave Dellinger, "More Power Than We Know: The People's Movement Toward Democracy").
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Dave Dellinger, "More Power Than We Know: The People's Movement Toward Democracy," Anchor Press/Doubleday, 1975.

target1: Austrian Airliner en route to Tel Aviv
gname: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, Gen Cmd (PFLP-GC)
Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, Gen Cmd (PFLP-GC)

summary: 2/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb at a police car in front of the Charles Street Police Station in Greenwich, New York, United States.  Another bomb was thrown to the pavement  seventy-five feet away.  The attacks caused no damages or casualties.
scite1: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Are Exploded at Home of N.Y. Panther Trial Judge," New York Times, February 21, 1970.

summary: 2/21/1970: Two Military Recruiting Stations in the vicinity of Brooklyn College were firebombed by unknown perpetrators in New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the recruiting stations sustained minor damages before the fire was extinguished.
target1: Army Recruiting Booth and Navy Recruiting Booth
propcomment: The booths were scorched
scite1: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Are Exploded at Home of N.Y. Panther Trial Judge," New York Times, February 21, 1970.

summary: 2/21/1970: The Weathermen claimed credit for bombing the residence of State Supreme Court Justice John Murtagh New York, United States.  The attack caused no casualties but the house sustained minor damages.  Judge Murtagh was presiding over a trial of thirteen Black Panther members at the time.    Anti-Vietnam war and pro-Black Panther graffiti was left at the scene of the attack.
motive: Protest Vietnam War and show support for Black Panthers.
weapdetail: Gasoline in bottles detonated by firecrackers
propcomment: Brick wall was partially scorched and several panes in a window were damaged.
addnotes: It was suspected that this attack might have been related to 197002210003, 197002210004, and 197002200002.  However, the Weathermen only claimed credit for this attack in a letter to the New York Times, and did not mention participation in any other attacks on February 21. Written in front of the house was graffiti stating "Free Panther 21" and "Vietcong Have Won." The bombs were placed on the front doorway, next to a window, and under the Murtagh's car.  Murtagh and his family were placed in the protection of the police as a result of the attack.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.
scite3: Bernardine Dohrn, "An End to Violence?" New York Times, January 19, 1971.

summary: 2/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb into the residence of James C. Perrill in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the house was damaged.  The attack occurred during heightened racial tensions due to the integration of Denver City Schools and Perrill was  a conservative school board member.
motive: Protest anti-integrationists of the Denver City Schools.
propcomment: It is unknown if the firebomb caused any damage
addnotes: This is one of many attacks in Denver resulting from school integration.  Other incidents include 197002060001 and 197002240002.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 2/22/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw kerosene flare pots at the Wari House Dormitory which housed the Black Women's Cooperative at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, United States.  The incendiary tossed at the dormitory failed to ignite, but an incendiary thrown through the window of a car parked in front of the dormitory burst into flames and caused minor damages to the vehicle.  There were no casualties.
motive: To intimidate the African American community at Cornell University
propcomment: Car sustained minor damages and a broken window
addnotes: This attack occurred amidst heightened racial tensions at Cornell University.  A year earlier, unknown perpetrator burnt a cross in front of the Wari House dormitory.  Five weeks after the attack the Africana Studies and Research Center on campus was firebombed (197004010002).
scite1: "Flare Pot Hurled at Cornell House," New York Times, February 23, 1970.
scite2: Richard Phalon, "Fire Destroys the Black Studies Center at Cornell," New York Times, April 2, 1970.
scite3: Michael T. Kaufman, "Court Enjoins Violence at Cornell; Curfew Set," New York Times, April 10, 1970.

summary: 2/22/1970: Karl Armstrong, a member of the New Years Gang, attempted to bomb the Wisconsin Power and Light substation in Prairie du Sac, Wisconsin, United States.  Carrying thirteen sticks of dynamite he broke into the substation, but fled the scene when a night security guard arrived unexpectedly.  The substation supplied power to the Badger Ammunition Plant.
target1: Wisconsin Power and Light Company substation, Prairie du Sac
motive: To sabotage the Badger Ammunition Plant
weapdetail: Thirteen sticks of dynamite attached to a battery operated device
addnotes: The New Years Gang attempted to bomb the Wisconsin Ammunition Plant weeks earlier. (197001050001)  Karl Armstrong would be captured after participating in the deadly bombing of Sterling Hall at the University of Wisconsin on August 24, 1970.  (197008240001)
scite1: Tom Bates, "Rads: The 1970 Bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin and Its Aftermath," HarperCollinsPublishing, 1992.
scite2: David Newman, Sandra Sutherland, and Jon Stewart, "The Madison Bomb Story: The Death the FBI Saw, Heard and Won't Talk About," Mother Jones, February-March, 1979.
scite3: The Wisconsin Cartographers' Guild, "Wisconsin's Past and Present: A Historical Atlas," The University of Wisconsin Press, 2002.

summary: 2/23/1970: In a series of related attacks, unknown perpetrators bombed four separate power transmission poles in the Dakota City and Sioux City areas in Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties and none of the dynamite blasts broke off any of the poles.   These attacks were one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.
target1: Power Transmission Pole in the Dakota City/Sioux City area
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike in South Sioux City.
propcomment: None of the poles broke off
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/23/1970: In a series of related attacks, unknown perpetrators bombed four separate power transmission poles in the Dakota City and Sioux City areas in Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties and none of the dynamite blasts broke off any of the poles.   These attacks were one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.
target1: Power Transmission Pole in the Dakota City/Sioux City area
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike in South Sioux City.
propcomment: None of the poles broke off

There were no casualties and none of the dynamite blasts broke off any of the poles.   These attacks were one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.

summary: 2/23/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a dynamite bomb in front of the Selective Service Headquarters in Tucson, Arizona, United States. There were no casualties, however, all of the windows of the building shattered.
motive: Protest the draft.
propcomment: All of the windows of the buildings were broken
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Steven V. Roberts, "Bombings on Rise Over the Nation," New York Times, March 13, 1970.

summary: 2/24/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a pipe bomb in front of the house of Wilfred Keyes in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties, however, the front porch was destroyed and many windows were shattered.  Keyes was the lead plaintiff in a court case calling for the desegregation of Denver City Schools.
motive: Protest the desegregation of Denver City Schools.
propcomment: Front porch was destroyed and windows in the house were shattered
addnotes: This is one of many attacks in Denver resulting from school integration.  Other incidents include 197002060001 and 197002210006.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anna Alejo, "Alejo: Keys to Success," Rocky Mountain News, January 28, 2006.
scite3: James Brooke, "Court Says Denver Can End Forced Busing," New York Times, September 17, 1995.

summary: 2/24/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into the Armory at the University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana, United States.  There were no casualties but the firebomb caused $2,000 in damages.  The offices of the R.O.T.C. were located in the Armory
motive: Protest secret government research at the University of Illinois and the R.O.T.C. program.
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail thrown through the window of the Armory
addnotes: The attack occurred a day after the Illiac project was approved by the University. Of Illinois  The project brought a high powered computer to campus that would be used mostly for government research.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Patrick D. Kennedy, "Reactions Against the Vietnam War and Military-Related Targets on Campus: The University of Illinois as a Case Study, 1965-1972," Illinois Historical Journal, 1991.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 2/27/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb in the Behavioral Sciences Building at the University of Colorado at Boulder in Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the building was damaged.
motive: Protesting scholarship money that was set aside for minorities but had yet to be awarded
addnotes: This attack occurred the week before first lady Pat Nixon planned on visiting the University of Colorado.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Marie Smith, "Heavy Security Highlights Pat's Colorado Visit," Washington Post, March 5, 1970.
scite3: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 3/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the office of the Air Force R.O.T.C. at the University of Colorado in Boulder, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the R.O.T.C. training facility sustained an estimated $2,000 in damages.
target1: Air Force R.O.T.C. at University of Colorado
motive: Protest the Vietnam War and the R.O.T.C.
weapdetail: Explosive device made with 5-gallon can of gasoline
propcomment: Door destroyed and walls damaged
addnotes: The perpetrators painted signs on nearby the building saying "Imperialism Burns" and "Vietnam Napalm R.O.T.C.." This attack occurred the week before first lady Pat Nixon planned on visiting the University of Colorado.  The incident also occurred on the same day as 197003010006 and 197003010007.  No records of the R.O.T.C. were destroyed in the attack.  This incident might also be related to the minority fees issue like 197002270001.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Colorado R.O.T.C. Blast Attributed to Arsonists," Washington Post, March 3, 1970.
scite3: Robert W. Patterson, "Crime & the American Response," Facts on File, 1973

summary: 3/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the headquarters of the Selective Service in Colorado Springs, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained moderate damages.
motive: Protest the War in Vietnam and sabotage the draft
propcomment: Moderate damage to building
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Colorado R.O.T.C. Blast Attributed to Arsonists," Washington Post, March 3, 1970.
scite3: Steven V. Roberts, "Bombings on Rise Over the Nation," New York Times, March 13, 1970.

summary: 3/1/1970: In a series of two incidents that were possibly related, unknown perpetrators firebombed a University of Colorado campus police vehicle in Boulder, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the car was damaged.
addnotes: This incident might be part of a multiple attack with 197003010008. This attack occurred the week before first lady Pat Nixon planned on visiting the University of Colorado.  This attack occurred the same day as 197003010005.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.
scite3: Nan Robertson, "The First Lady Visits Projects in Restive Boulder," New York Times, March 5, 1970.

summary: 3/2/1970: In a series of two incidents that were possibly related, unknown perpetrators bombed a city police car in Boulder, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the car was damaged.
addnotes: This incident might be part of a multiple attack with 197003010007.  This attack occurred the week before first lady Pat Nixon planned on visiting the University of Colorado.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.
scite3: Nan Robertson, "The First Lady Visits Projects in Restive Boulder," New York Times, March 5, 1970.

summary: 3/2/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into the house of Frank Schaeffer, the president of the Cleveland Fraternal Order of Police, in Cleveland, Ohio, United States.  There were no casualties but the fire caused an estimated $200 in damages.  Schaeffer had recently defended the actions of Cleveland Police Officers during the 1968 racial disorders.
target2: Fraternal Order of Police, Cleveland Ohio
motive: To protest Frank Schaeffer's defense of the Cleveland Police Deparment during the 1968 Glenville racial riots
propcomment: Carpeting and two chairs were damaged
scite1: "Home of Police Officer Bombed," Toledo Blade, March 2, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

target1: Garrigues, permanent spanish delegaet to Unesco

summary: 3/3/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a foreign-made car painted red in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the car was damaged.
addnotes: This attack was linked with incidents 197003040003 and 197003050002.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 3/3/1970: Four left wing radicals set off a dynamite bomb at a post office in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the building and a vehicle were damaged.
target1: Post Office in Seattle's University District
propcomment: Building and vehicle damaged
addnotes: Two of the perpetrators were members of Students for a Democratic Society and the other two perpetrators were known sympathizers of the organization.  There is a source claiming that one of the perpetrators of the attack, Jeff Desmond, was actually working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (See: Dave Dellinger, "More Power Than We Know: The People's Movement Toward Democracy").
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Earl Caldwell, "Fear Grows In Seattle As Police Urge F.B.I. Help On Bombings," New York Times, April 26, 1970.
scite3: Dave Dellinger, "More Power Than We Know: The People's Movement Toward Democracy," Anchor Press/Doubleday, 1975.

summary: 3/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a time bomb in a Barracks at the Oakland Army Base in California, United States.  The bomb was subsequently discovered and disarmed. The base was used as a departing point for United States troops heading to Vietnam.
motive: Sabotage the US Army war efforts and protest the Vietnam War
weapdetail: Two and one half pound block of C-4 wired to a commercial blasting cap and timing device
addnotes: When the bomb was discovered the barracks were evacuated.  This incident might be related with 197003040002.  They both occurred on the same day in a distance of around thirty miles from each other.  However, different types of explosive devices were used.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Army Disarms Time Bomb at Base in Oakland," Washington Post, March 5, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Found and Disarmed At Oakland Army Base," New York Times, March 5, 1970.

summary: 3/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb on a railroad car in Martinez, California, United States.  The bomb was subsequently discovered and disarmed.  The railroad car was used to transport acid.
weapdetail: Four sticks of dynamite triggered by a mousetrap
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 3/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a foreign-made car painted red in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the car was damaged.
addnotes: This attack was linked with incidents 197003030002 and 197003050002.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 3/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at the University District Post Office in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties, however, the side of the building was damaged.
propcomment: Side of building damaged
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 3/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a foreign-made car painted red in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the car was heavily damaged.
propcomment: Vehicle heavily damaged
addnotes: This attack was linked with incidents 197003030002 and 197003040003.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 3/5/1970: Unknown Puerto Rican Nationalists assassinated two United States Navy personal stationed in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The incident was in response to the death of Antonia Martinez Lagaras, who was shot and killed during a confrontation between students and police in front of the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Puerto Rico, Rio Piedras a day earlier.
target1: Two members of the United States Navy
motive: To protest United States presence in Puerto Rico and revenge the death of Antonia Martinez Lagares
addnotes: Conflicting reports attribute the incident to the Armed Commandos of Liberation and the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA).
scite1: Committee on the Judiciary  United States Senate, "Terroristic Activity: The Cuban Connection in Puerto Rico; Castro's Hand in Puerto Rican and U.S. Terrorism," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: William Sater, "Puerto Rican Terrorists: A Possible Threat to U.S. Energy Installations?," RAND, October 1981.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqués from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

target1: Sean Holley, U.S. labor attache, U.S. embassy

summary: 3/6/1970: In a series of related unsuccessful attacks, suspected members of the Weathermen placed thirty-four sticks of dynamite at the Detroit Police Department building in Michigan, United States.  The bombs were subsequently discovered and  disarmed.
motive: To kill police
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: W. Mark Felt, "The FBBI Pyramid From the Inside," G. P. Putnam's Sons, 1979.
scite3: John Castellucci, "The Big Dance," Dodd, Mead & Company, 1986.

summary: 3/6/1970: In a series of related unsuccessful attacks, suspected members of the Weathermen tossed a package containing dynamite through a window of the Detroit Police Officers Association in Michigan, United States.  The dynamite was  discovered and subsequently disarmed.
motive: To kill police
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: John Castellucci, "The Big Dance," Dodd, Mead & Company, 1986.
scite3: W. Mark Felt, "The FBBI Pyramid From the Inside," G. P. Putnam's Sons, 1979.

summary: 3/9/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed Shiloh Baptist Church, a predominantly African American Church, in Bridgeport, Connecticut, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained minor damages.
propcomment: Minor damage
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 3/9/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed an incendiary bomb underneath the Air Force R.O.T.C. building at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, New Mexico, United States.  The bomb was discovered and disarmed fifteen minutes before it was set to explode.
target1: Air Force R.O.T.C. at University of New Mexico
motive: Protest the R.O.T.C. program and Vietnam War
addnotes: Special state police were ordered by the governor to investigate the incident.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "S.F. State Protest Ends, Off-Campus Rampage Blocked," Washington Post, March 11, 1970.

target1: Memre Buku Garrison (HQ of Surinam Junta) Guard Post

location: The editorial office of the newspaper Daily Jang in Karachi
summary: 10/23/2001: The editorial offices of the newspaper Daily Jang received an anthrax-laden letter in Karachi, Sindh province, Pakistan.  No staff members were infected by the anthrax.  No group claimed responsibility and specific motive is unknown; however, the newspaper has generally supported President Pervez Musharraf, a staunch supporter of the United States war against the Taliban.
target1: Staff members of the Daily Jang newspaper
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the newspaper has generally supported President Pervez Musharraf, a staunch supporter of the United States war against the Taliban.
addnotes: The newspaper had received letters in the past that were laced with a white powder, but the powder had always tested negative for anthrax
scite1: "Pakistani daily says finds anthrax spores," Reuters, November 1, 2001.
scite2: Nadeem Afzal, "Pakistani newspaper evacuates offices after anthrax test comes back positive," Associated Press, November 2, 2001.

location: Waimulang village in South Buru subdistrict on Buru island
summary: 11/1/2001: Hundreds of armed assailants attacked Waimulang village on Buru island, Maluku province, Indonesia.  The assailants were from the western part of the region and were armed with grenades, improvised explosive devices, and standard weapons.  Three villagers were killed and ten houses were burned down; thousands of villagers fled the attack.  Specific motive is unknown; however, Waimulang village is predominantly Christian and Maluku province has been the site of violent conflict between Christians and Muslims for two years.
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, Waimulang village is predominantly Christian and Maluku province has been the site of violent conflict between Christians and Muslims for two years.
weapdetail: Improvised explosive devices, grenades, and standard weapons, along with fire
propcomment: At least ten houses burned down
addnotes: It is unclear whether the attackers were Muslim.
scite1: "New violence kills three in riot-torn Indonesian spice islands: report," Agence France-Presse, November 2, 2001.
scite2: "Fresh clash breaks out in Maluku, Indonesia," Xinhua News Agency, November 2, 2001.

summary: 11/03/2001: Three Indian army personnel were killed and five injured when three Lashkar-e Taiba fighters attacked an army camp in Anantnag district of South Kashmir. The attack was carried out with RPGs and grenades. A Lashkar-e Taiba spokesman claimed the attack.
target1: Indian soldiers at an army camp in Anantnag district of South Kashmir
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: RPG's and grenades were used in the attack.
scite1: “Three soldiers killed, five injured in suicide attack,” The Press Trust of India, November 3, 2001.

summary: 11/03/2001: Pierre Belanger, a Canadian citizen was kidnapped in Zamboanga, Philippines. A caller identifying himself as an Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG) member demanded a ransom from the victim's brother. They requested $160,000 Cdn. The outcome of this kidnapping was not detailed in reports.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The outcome of this kidnapping was not reported.
scite1: Abdul Latheef, “Canadian Kidnapped in the Philippines: Military Says it’s Investigating,” Canadian Press, November 10, 2001.
scite2: Abdul Latheef, “Canadian Kidnapped in the Philippines: Military Says it’s Investigating,” St John’s Telegram, November 11, 2001.

summary: 11/4/2001: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped Judge Juan Posada Soto and three lawyers from Caldas, Antioquia Department, Colombia.  No group claimed responsibility and the specific motive is unknown.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: This may have been a kidnapping for ransom and purely profit-motivated.
scite1: "Police say 18 people kidnapped across Colombia," Agence France-Presse, November 4, 2001.
scite2: "Leftist rebels kill three policemen, kidnap at least 11 people in Colombia," Associated Press, November 4, 2001.
scite3: "Colombia - Kidnapping. Over the weekend, 17 people kidnapped in Colombia," EFE News Service, November 5, 2001.

summary: 11/3/2001: Members of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) set up a roadblock in Casare Department, Colombia.  They abducted eight truck drivers.  The outcome of the kidnapping and the specific motive is unknown.

motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
addnotes: This may have been a kidnapping for ransom and purely profit-motivated.
scite1: "Colombia leftist rebels kill 3 cops," Associated Press, November 5, 2001.
scite2: "Leftist rebels kill three policemen, kidnap at least 11 people in Colombia," Associated Press, November 4, 2001.

location: The offices of Upali Newspapers in Colombo
summary: 11/3/2001: Unidentified individuals left a grenade in the offices of Upali Newspapers in Colombo, Western Province, Sri Lanka.  The pin on the grenade was pulled but it failed to explode; experts safely defused it.  No group claimed responsibility for it and the specific motive is unknown.
target1: The staff and offices of Upali Newspapers
motive: Unknown
addnotes: One source speculates that the grenade was left there in order to avoid a security search
scite1: "Grenade attack on Sri Lanka newspaper office," Agence France-Presse, November 3, 2001.
scite2: "Grenade defused at Sri Lankan newspaper; no injuries reported," Associated Press, November 3, 2001.

summary: 11/04/2001: Two Israelis were killed and between 35 and 46 others were injured when a Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) gunman opened fire on a bus in the French Hill section of Jerusalem, Israel. The gunmen was killed by Israelis at the scene. Both HAMAS and PIJ claimed the attack which was later determined to be a PIJ operation.
target1: Civilians on a bus in the French Hill section of Jerusalem
target2: Public bus in the French Hill section of Jerusalem
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The gunmen used a M-16 assault rifle.
propcomment: The bus was damaged in the attack.
scite1: “Palestinian opens fire on bus, killing 2; more than 40 wounded; Israel withdraws from West Bank city,” The Baltimore Sun, November 5, 2001.

summary: 11/05/2001: Unknown perpetrated attacked Munini, Burundi. Munini's head, a veterinary officer, a health official and five soldiers were killed in the attack. During the attack a health center was looted and burned. No one claimed the attack.
motive: Unknown
propcomment: A health center was burned down.
scite1: “Twenty-four killed in rebel attack in south,” Bujumbura Radio Burundi, November 6, 2001.

location: This is attack occurred near Grozny.
summary: 11/05/2001: A Russian armored personnel carrier was destroyed by a landmine near Grozny, Chechnya. Five of its occupants were killed and another five wounded. Mojahedin from the Mojahedin of the Lechi Dudayev subunit committed the attack.
target1: Russian military carrier near Grozny, Chechnya
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Five Russians killed in Groznyy land mine blast,” Marsho News Agency, November 6, 2001.

summary: 11/05/2001: An explosive device was discovered and defused at the Temple of Concord at the Valley of Temples archaeological site in Agrigento, Italy. The device was connected to a slow match and could have caused serious material damage had it detonated. Police found a piece of white fabric with slogans hailing Afghanistan and Allah near the scene of the explosion, but have ruled out the possibility that the attack was perpetrated by Islamic fundamentalists
target1: Temple of Concord at the Valley of Temples archaeological site in Agrigento, Italy
target2: Tourist visiting the Temple of Concord at the Valley of Temples archaeological site in Agrigento, Italy
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Italy: Investigators treating temple bomb as ‘attempted massacre’,” Rome ANSA, November 6, 2001.

summary: 11/05/2001: A 30 kilogram car bomb composed of homemade explosives failed to fully detonate in Birmingham, England. The device, which was believed by police to have been planted by the Real Irish Republican Army (RIRA)was disarmed after it failed to fully explode. There were no injuries.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Rachel Donnelly “'Serious loss of life' had car bomb fully detonated,” The Irish Times, November 5, 2001.
scite2: Vikram Dodd and Rosie Cowan “Real Irish Republican Army (RIRA) 'meant to kill': Police say Real Irish Republican Army (RIRA) meant bomb to kill,” The Guardian, November 5, 2001.

summary: 11/05/2001: Ian Jacob Wallace, acting on behalf of the Earth Liberation Front (ELF) attempted to destroy two forestry buildings at the Michigan Technological University campus by planting two firebombs, made of combustible liquids, ignition sources and timers, outside the buildings. In this case, the building targeted was the U.S. Forest Service Engineering Laboratory. There were no casualties in the incident, nor damages as the devices were found unexploded because the timers failed to trigger the bombs to ignite. The devices were subsequently defused by authorities. The motive was to "destroy tree research and intimidate the public."  Wallace pleaded guilty in 2008 to charges for this incident, and was sentenced in 2009, to three years in Federal prison.
motive: The buildings were being used for researching the genetic engineering of plants, which Wallace believed was detrimental to the environment, and he wanted to deter government agencies and others from supporting this type of research.
weapdetail: An incendiary device made of combustible liquids, ignition sources and timing device
addnotes: Wallace had an accomplice who traveled with him to Houghton to commit the attack, but this person is unknown.
scite1: Eric Lindquist, "Former honor student turns eco-terrorist," The Leader-Telegram, October 4, 2009.
scite2: "Information Issued by U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Michigan on March 27: Sentencing in 2001 Eco-Terrorism Attempt at Michigan Technological University," US Fed News, April 13, 2009.
scite3: " N.Y. Student gets 3 years in prison for eco-crime," Associated Press State & Local Wire, March 23, 2009.

Wallace pleaded guilty in 2008 to charges for this incident, and was sentenced in 2009, to three years in Federal prison.

summary: 11/06/2001: A car bomb exploded on a busy road during rush hour in Madrid, Spain injuring 95 people. The attack was targeting Juan Junquera, the Secretary General of the Scientific Policy Department who was driving by at the time of the explosion. Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Juan Junquera, Secretary General of the Scientific Policy Department
motive: Unknown
scite1: Jean-Herve Deiller “60 injured as car bomb rocks Madrid suburb,” Agence France Presse, November 6, 2001.

target1: Australian International School in Jakarta, Indonesia
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Blast rocks Australian school in Indonesia,” United Press International, November 7, 2001.

motive: Unknown

summary: 11/06/2001: Suspected rebels of the Movement of the Democratic Forces of Casamance (MFDC) attacked two vehicles in Manjalago, Ziguinchor. During the attack four people were killed and another four wounded.

summary: 11/06/2001: Chechen rebels used grenade launchers to attack the Grozneftegaz oil depot in Grozny, Chechnya. The facility was destroyed along with at least 5,000 tons of oil. There were no injuries in the attack.

motive: Unknown
propcomment: The oil facility was destroyed.
addnotes: The attack put the facility completely out of operation.
scite1: “Russia: Chechen rebels attack oil depot,” Moscow Russian TV RTR, November 6, 2001.

location: The town of Munini, 140 kilometers from Bujumbura
summary: 11/05/2001: Approximately 300 Hutu rebels attacked the town of Munini in Bururi province, Burundi.  The assailants targeted the military post first, killing six soldiers.  They proceeded to attack the villagers, killing at least 18 civilians.  The attackers looted shops and homes before burning them down, along with the health center.
target1: The military post located in Munini
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, the incident occurred during escalated violence following the inauguration of the new government.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
propcomment: Shops, the health center, and the administrator's office were burnt down
addnotes: A Hutu spokesperson claims that no civilians were killed.
scite1: Jocelyne Sambira, "Government official claims rebels kill 24 people in southern Burundi," Associated Press, November 6, 2001.
scite2: "Rebel attack claims 25 lives in southern Burundi," Agence France-Presse, November 6, 2001.
scite3: "Burundi rebels kill 35 civilians - local officials," Reuters, November 6, 2001.

location: A primary school in eastern Ruyigi province, approximately 105 kilometers from Bujumbura
summary: 11/07/2001: Hutu rebels kidnapped 58 children and four teachers from a primary school in Ruyigi province, Burundi.  Security forces surrounded the assailants and freed the children and teachers.  Specific motive is unknown; however, Hutu rebels have kidnapped children in the past to use as fighters.
target1: Teachers and students at a primary school
motive: Specific motive is unknown; however, sources note that Hutu rebels kidnap children and force them to become fighters.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
addnotes: It is unclear when the children were actually kidnapped and how long they were held captive.
scite1: Maria Eismont, "Burundi Hutu rebels 'kidnap children'," The Guardian, November 8, 2001.
scite2: "Burundi army says frees kidnapped schoolchildren," Reuters, November 7, 2001.

summary: 11/07/2001: Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) members shot and killed a provincial judge in Getxo, Spain. Magistrate Jose Maria Lidon Corbi was shot at least twice in the back of the head as he drove out of his garage in Getxo, a neighborhood on the outskirts of the Basque port of Bilbao”
target1: Jose Maria Lidon Corbi, Spanish judge
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The assassination was designed to hit the Spanish judicial system, which ETA considers as "another instrument of aggression used to punish Basque citizens and absolve those who oppress the Basque homeland."
scite1: “Basque separatists claim Madrid car bomb, judge’s murder,” Agence France Presse, November 15, 2001.
scite2: “ETA claims responsibility for car bomb in Madrid and killing of a judge in the Basque region,” Associated Press Worldstream, November 15, 2001.
scite3: “ETA claims responsibility for car bomb,” Associated Press Online, November 15, 2001.

weapdetail: He used a Kalashnikov assault rifle.

summary: 11/09/2001: A suspected suicide bomber of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) threw himself onto a police jeep in eastern Sri Lanka. He missed his target, but the explosion killed the bomber and wounded three policemen.

motive: Unknown

summary: 11/9/2001: Members of Mujahedin Kompak threw homemade bombs through the windows of the Petra Protestant Church in Jakarta, Indonesia during an evening service.  One of the bombs detonated causing a strong blast and broken windows, but no casualties. Three unexploded bombs were found inside the church.
motive: The attack was intended to incite a sectarian conflict.  It was aimed at two priests whom the perpetrators accused of engaging in propaganda to stigmatize Muslims.
propcomment: The explosion shattered one window and nails contained in the bomb damaged part of the church's roof.
scite1: "Blast at Jakarta Church," Agence France Presse, November 9, 2001.

summary: 11/11/2001: A breakaway faction of Popular Liberation Army (EPL) kidnapped at least 15 musicians near El Tarra, Norte de Santander Department, Colombia.  The musicians belonged to a popular band led by Alfredo Guteirrez.  The assailants called Guteirrez and demanded that the military begin withdrawing from five cities or they would kill the musicians one by one.  The musicians were released on November 28, 2001, following the intervention of the Red Cross and the ombudsman.
target1: Musicians belong to a popular band
motive: The assailants demanded the demilitarization of five cities in Norte de Santander Department.
weapdetail: No specific mention of weapons was made.
addnotes: Two sources state that 15 musicians were kidnapped while one source states that 19 were released.
scite1: "Colombia - kidnapping.  Colombian vallenato star pleads for release of kidnapped band," EFE News Service, November 21, 2001.
scite2: "Colombia - kidnapping/musicians.  Colombia demands release of musicians abducted by rebels," EFE News Service, November 20, 2001.
scite3: "Colombian rebels free 19 hostages," Agence France-Presse, November 28, 2001.

motive: Unknown
scite1: James Bennet, “Israeli is Slain by Gunmen; Palestinian Dies in Explosion,” New York Times, November 12, 2001.

location: The attack took place in the village Markapalli, Malkangiri district, Orissa, India.
summary: 06/16/2010: On Wednesday night, in the village of Markapalli, Malkangiri district, Orissa, India, Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) cadres killed Manoram Durua, a jawan serving under Border Security Force (BSF) of the Shasastra Seema Bal (SSB). Reportedly, Durau returned to his native village to attend the Raj festival when an armed group of eight to10 Maoists called on him at his home and asked him to accompany them. The Maoists slit his throat and then dumped his body near the village. No damages were reported. Maoist posters left in the village issued warnings to SPO and village guards to quit their jobs. The attack and warnings resulted in the resignation of five people in Kalimela police station jurisdiction.
target1: A border security force officer was targeted in the attack.
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: Unknown sharp weapons were used in the attack.
addnotes: The available sources listed the attack type for these attacks from a shooting to a stabbing, and since no majority attack type was reported, the attack type originally entered was kept.
scite1: Hindu, “The Hindu (English): Naxals Kill Jawan,” Access World News, Hindu, June 22, 2010.
scite2: Pioneer, “Maoists Kill BSF Jawan in Malkangiri,” LexisNexis Academic, Hindustan Times, June 18, 2010.

location: The attack took place in central Karrada district, Baghdad, Iraq.
summary: 06/16/2010: On Wednesday, in central Karrada district, Baghdad, a roadside improvised explosive device targeting the vehicle of an Education Ministry official wounded three civilians and damaging the vehicle. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: The targets of this attack was the vehicle of an Education Ministry official.
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
propcomment: The attack caused an unknown amount of property damage.
scite1: Reuters, "FACTBOX-Security Developments in Iraq, June 16," Reuters, June 16, 2010, http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/MUH643933.htm.
scite2: National Counterterrorism Center, "Three Bodyguards, Two Civilians Wounded in IED Attack in Baghdad, Iraq," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, October 28, 2010.

summary: 06/16/2010: On Wednesday, in Datta Khel, Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan, suspected Taliban militants held and shot dead an alleged murderer before a large gathering in North Waziristan. Waheed Khan, a 28-year-old resident of North Waziristan, was killed before a crowd of 200 for allegedly killing a tribesman on 06/12/2010. No group claimed responsibility, although it was widely believed the Taliban was responsible.
target1: An alleged murderer was targeted in the attack.
motive: The specific motive for the attack was punishment for an alleged murder.
weapdetail: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
scite1: National Counterterrorism Center, "One Civilian Killed in Armed Attack by Suspected Taliban in Datta Khel, Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, October 20, 2010.
scite2: Indian Express, “Pak Scan,” LexisNexis Academic, Indian Express, June 17, 2010.
scite3: Statesman, “Briefs,” LexisNexis Academic, Statesman, June 18, 2010.

No group claimed responsibility, but the Tehrik-i-Taliban was suspected. No damages were reported.

location: The attack took place in Kirundo.
summary: 06/16/2010: On Wednesday night, in Kirundo, Kirundo district, Burundi, unknown militants threw three grenades at homes. This attack was one of three related attacks that also targeted Ngozi and Bujumbura. One house was damaged while there were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the attack but the National Liberation Forces (FNL) or another opposition group is suspected.
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: Three grenades were used in the attack.
propcomment: One house was damaged in the attack.
scite1: National Counterterrorism Center, "One House Damaged in Grenade Attacks in Kirundo, Kirundo, Burundi," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, October 27, 2010.
scite2: BBC Monitoring Africa, "Unidentified People Throw Grenades in Northern Burundi," LexisNexis Academic, BBC Monitoring Africa, June 17, 2010.
scite3: Gus Selassie, "Latest Grenade Blasts Underline New Security Concerns in Burundi," LexisNexis Academic, World Markets Research Centre, June 18, 2010.

location: The attack took place in Ramadi, Al Anbar, Iraq.
summary: 06/16/2010: On Wednesday, Ramadi, Al Anbar, Iraq, assailants detonated a magnetic improvised explosive device attached to a vehicle, wounding one civilian and damaging the vehicle. No group claimed responsibility.
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: A vehicle borne improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
propcomment: The attack caused an unknown amount of property damage.

location: The attack took place in the Al Asri district of Tikrit, Salah ad Din, Iraq.
summary: 06/16/2010: On Wednesday, in the Al Asri district of Tikrit, Salah ad Din, Iraq, unidentified assailants detonated a magnetic improvised explosive device attached to a vehicle, wounding the driver and damaging the vehicle. No group claimed responsibility.
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: A vehicle borne improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
